attributes.text:
A page is a widget which provides a screen with which users can interact in order to do something. Most times a page provides a single task or a group of related tasks.

A qooxdoo mobile application is usually composed of one or more loosely bound pages. Typically there is one page that presents the “main” view.

Pages can have one or more child widgets from the {@link qx.ui.mobile} namespace. Normally a page provides a {@link qx.ui.mobile.navigationbar.NavigationBar} for the navigation between pages.

To navigate between two pages, just call the {@link #show} method of the page that should be shown. Depending on the used page manager a page transition will be animated. There are several animations available. Have a look at the {@link qx.ui.mobile.page.Manager} manager or {@link qx.ui.mobile.layout.Card} card layout for more information.

A page has predefined lifecycle methods that get called by the used page manager when a page gets shown. Each time another page is requested to be shown the currently shown page is stopped. The other page, will be, if shown for the first time, initialized and started afterwards. For all called lifecycle methods an event is fired.

Call of the {@link #show} method triggers the following lifecycle methods:

  • initialize: Initializes the page to show
  • start: Gets called when the page to show is started
  • stop: Stops the current page

IMPORTANT: Define all child widgets of a page when the {@link #initialize} lifecycle method is called, either by listening to the {@link #initialize} event or overriding the {@link #_initialize} method. This is because a page can be instanced during application startup and would then decrease performance when the widgets would be added during constructor call. The initialize event and the {@link #_initialize} lifecycle method are only called when the page is shown for the first time.
Event handler. Called when the back button of the device was pressed.
Event handler. Called when the device is ready.
Event handler. Called when the menu button of the device was pressed.
Fired when the method {@link #back} is called and not prevented by {@link qx.application.Mobile#back}. Data indicating whether the action was triggered by a key event or not.
Fired when the lifecycle method {@link #initialize} is called
Fired when the method {@link #menu} is called
Fired when the lifecycle method {@link #pause} is called
Fired when the lifecycle method {@link #resume} is called
Fired when the lifecycle method {@link #start} is called
Fired when the lifecycle method {@link #stop} is called
Fired when the method {@link #wait} is called
new value of the property
previous value of the property (null if it was not yet set).

Applies changes of the property value of the property lifeCycleState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #lifeCycleState}.
Whether the back action was triggered by a key event.
Override this method if you want to perform a certain action when back is called.
Whether the exit should be exit or not. Return true
Override this method if you would like to perform a certain action when initialize is called.
Override this method if you would like to perform a certain action when pause is called.
Override this method if you would like to perform a certain action when resume is called.
Override this method if you would like to perform a certain action when start is called.
Override this method if you would like to perform a certain action when stop is called.
Override this method if you would like to perform a certain action when wait is called.
Whether the back action was triggered by a key event.

Fires the back event. Call this method if you want to request a back action. For Android PhoneGap applications this method gets called by the used page manager when the back button was pressed. Return true to exit the application.

The back request can prevented by calling the {@link qx.event.type.Event#preventDefault} on the {@link qx.application.Mobile#back} event.
Whether the exit should be exit or not. Return true

Returns the (computed) value of the property lifeCycleState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #lifeCycleState}.
(Computed) value of lifeCycleState.

Lifecycle method. Called by the page manager when the page is shown. Fires the initialize event. You should create and add all your child widgets of the view, either by listening to the {@link #initialize} event or overriding the {@link #_initialize} method. This is because a page can be instanced during application startup and would then decrease performance when the widgets would be added during constructor call. The {@link #_initialize} lifecycle method and the initialize are only called once when the page is shown for the first time.
Initial value for property lifeCycleState.

Calls the apply method and dispatches the change event of the property lifeCycleState with the default value defined by the class developer. This function can only be called from the constructor of a class.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #lifeCycleState}.
the default value
Returns the status of the initialization of the page.
Whether the page is already initialized or not
Only used by Android PhoneGap applications. Called by the used page manager when the menu button was pressed. Fires the menu event.
Lifecycle method. Not used right now. Should be called when the current page is interrupted, e.g. by a dialog, so that page view updates can be interrupted. Fires the pause event.

Resets the user value of the property lifeCycleState.

The computed value falls back to the next available value e.g. appearance, init or inheritance value depeneding on the property configuration and value availability.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #lifeCycleState}.

Lifecycle method. Not used right now. Should be called when the current page is resuming from a interruption, e.g. when a dialog is closed, so that page can resume updating the view. Fires the resume event.
New value for property lifeCycleState.

Sets the user value of the property lifeCycleState.

For further details take a look at the property definition: {@link #lifeCycleState}.
The unmodified incoming value.

Lifecycle method. Called by the page manager after the {@link #initialize} method when the page is shown. Fires the start event. You should register all your event listener when this event occurs, so that no page updates are done when page is not shown.

Lifecycle method. Called by the page manager when another page is shown. Fires the stop event. You should unregister all your event listener when this event occurs, so that no page updates are down when page is not shown.
Lifecycle method. Not used right now. Should be called when the current page waits for data request etc. Fires the wait event.
The current active life cycle state of this page.
